challenges-to-voters-at-the-polling-plac.name: Challenges to Voters at the Polling Place

subtopics.fact: Any registered elector or poll watcher of a county
Challenges are permitted at the polls on Election Day.
subtopics.subtopic: What are the restrictions on polling place challenges?

citations: Per e-mail from Maria Matthews, Assistant General Counsel to the Florida Department of State, on 5/17/10
subtopics.fact: There are no specific limits as to what may be stated in a written challenge on the claim that the voter is "attempting to vote illegally."
subtopics.subtopic: What are the allowed reasons on which a voter can be challenged?

citations: Per e-mail from Maria Matthews, Assistant General Counsel to the Florida Department of State, on 5/17/10
subtopics.fact: The challenge is executed on a "reason to believe" standard. It will be up to the canvassing board as to whether grounds have been sufficiently stated.
subtopics.subtopic: Is there a requirement for the challenger to provide cause or evidence?

subtopics.fact: A person challenged based on their legal residence may fill out a change of legal residence and if they are then qualified to vote in that precinct, they may vote a regular ballot. All other challenged voters will have to vote a provisional ballot. The voter must then present to the Supervisor of Elections evidence of his or her eligibility by 5 pm. on the 2nd day following Election Day in order for the provisional ballot to count.
subtopics.subtopic: How does a voter defend their eligibility to vote if they are challenged?
Who must show ID to vote?

subtopics.fact:
Every voter will be asked to show a photo and signature identification at the polls. Acceptable forms of photo identification include:
  • Florida driver's license
  • Florida identification card issued by the Department of Highway Safety and Motor Vehicles
  • United States passport
  • Debit or credit card
  • Military identification
  • Student identification
  • Retirement center identification
  • Neighborhood association identification
  • Public assistance identification
If a voter's photo identification does not contain their signature, they will be required to show an additional identification that provides their signature.

citations: Per e-mail from Maria Matthews, Assistant General Counsel to the Florida Department of State, on 5/13/10
subtopics.fact: None. If a voter cannot present acceptable identification, they may vote a provisional ballot. A voter may have to provide additional evidence of their identity by 5 p.m. on the second day after the election in order for their ballot to count.
subtopics.subtopic: If a voter has no ID, are there alternatives such as an oath or witness?

subtopics.fact: Yes, as long as it is current and valid and has a photo. If it does not have a signature, additional identification with a signature may be required.
